proposals.reasoning: Most players have already coalesced around a Bob/Eve team for Mission 1, and both have clearly stated their approaches, which gives us accountable discussion afterward. A two-person first mission can’t hard-clear anyone, but putting two active, talkative players on it maximizes the behavioral info we get from both the mission result and their post-mission explanations, while minimizing early overcommitment to any tight pairing or trust circle.

votes.comment: Solid, information-rich first mission with two talkative players and no known evils; a reasonable start without overcommitting to any trust circle.
Standard info-gathering first mission with two active players; no strong reason to avoid it yet.

Mission 1 is low-risk and this team has broad support; sending two talkative players gives us maximum info from both the result and their later explanations, even though a success won’t clear either of them.
Eve is on the team, giving evil an immediate chance to sabotage and gather info with minimal risk to our cover.
I want to be on the first mission to gather info and influence how early reads form.
Early consensus team with two active players; good for gathering info without overcommitting, and rejecting now would look unnecessarily contrarian.
Standard info-gathering first team with two talkative players; no strong reason yet to distrust either, and a 2-person Mission 1 can’t give hard clears anyway.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d lean toward picking from people who haven’t said much yet, maybe someone like Bob or Eve, just to get some early info without risking too many unknown dynamics. I’d avoid stacking the team with people who are tightly defending each other this early.

I’m okay being on the first team, but I’d rather pair one quieter person with someone who’s already talking a bit—maybe something like me/Eve or Eve/Charlie—just so we get some early info without pretending to “clear” anyone yet.

I don’t hate a Bob/Eve or Eve/Charlie team to start, but we should treat any success as very soft info since a single good result here doesn’t clear anyone. I’m fine going on the mission if people want, but I’d slightly prefer at least one of Bob/Eve on it so we start building a read on them.

I’d like to see Eve on the first team with someone who’s been actively talking, like Bob or Charlie, so we at least get some early behavioral info to work with. I’m fine sitting out this one and weighing the reactions.

I’m fine being on the first mission, and I agree it makes sense to pair me with someone who’s been active like Bob so we actually have some discussion to analyze afterward. I’d slightly prefer Bob/Eve over Eve/Charlie just because Bob’s already framed a clear approach we can hold him accountable to.

Given how much Bob and Eve have already laid out their thinking, I’d be fine with a Bob/Eve team for Mission 1 so we at least get some accountable discussion afterward. I wouldn’t read too much into a single clean mission, but it’s a decent starting point.

I’m okay with a Bob/Eve first team since they’ve both laid out their thinking pretty clearly, but we should remember a clean mission doesn’t clear either of them and be ready to re-evaluate fast if anything feels off.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps Bob and me from pairing again, which everyone flagged as risky, while still including exactly one player from the first mission (me) so we’re not throwing away that information. Alice is widely trusted and has been on no missions yet, and Frank suggested a configuration like Alice–Charlie–Frank (or similar) with at most one of Bob/Eve, so Alice–Frank–Eve fits within that preference: two completely new players plus just one of the original mission members, and it avoids repeating the Bob–Eve combo that most people objected to.

votes.comment: I don’t like including both an untested player and someone from the failed first mission when we have safer options like Alice/Charlie/Grace that avoid that risk mix.
Eve was on the failed first mission, and I’ve already said I don’t want her back on a team this soon; I’d rather test new players without her first.
Eve is highly suspicious from the failed first mission; we can form a safer team of all-new players (e.g., Alice, Frank, Charlie/Grace) without including a likely spy.
Includes my fellow evil Eve with two untested players; good chance to sabotage again while looking reasonable given prior discussion about splitting Bob and Eve.
I’m on the team and it keeps suspicion focused on the Bob–Eve pairing while still letting me influence the mission.
I’m on the team and Eve is suspicious from the failed first mission, so this lineup gives evil a strong chance to sabotage again.
Eve is in the only known failing pair, and I’d rather test a completely new team like Alice/Charlie/Grace/Frank before trusting her again.

proposals.reasoning: The first mission failed with the Bob–Eve pair, so I want to avoid sending either of them for now and get a clean read on new players. Multiple people (Charlie, Grace, Eve) have expressed trust in an Alice–Charlie core, and I previously suggested including myself with that group to add a fresh, untested player. This team avoids the suspicious first-mission pair entirely, aligns with the general table preference for testing Alice and Charlie together, and brings in only one new variable—me—as leader, while giving us a strong information baseline if this mission passes or fails.

votes.comment: I still don’t want to include an untested player who keeps putting themselves on early teams after a fail; I’d rather see a combo like Alice/Charlie/Grace first for a cleaner read.

Eve is confirmed suspicious from Mission 1, and this team fully avoids both her and the failed Bob–Eve pair. Between Alice and Diana, Diana is more likely to be the deceptive one given her Mission 1 choice, so Alice is more likely good, making this a reasonable test team.
Team excludes the suspicious Bob–Eve pair and Diana, and as a known good to myself I’m comfortable testing Alice and Frank together here.
Keeps both first-mission suspects off the team and matches the table’s stated preferences, while still giving evil a chance that one of the unknowns is a teammate who can fail it.
No known evil is on this team, so from my perspective it risks giving the good side a clean pass with little information gained.
As scum, I want to be on missions I can sabotage; this team excludes the already-suspected Bob/Eve pair, so a fail here will shift suspicion onto this new group instead.
I’d rather wait to propose the Alice–Charlie–Grace team next, which multiple people (including me) already endorsed as safer and gives us a better shot at an all‑good mission.

discussion.content: Given the fail on the first mission, I’d rather not see both Bob and Eve go together again; mixing in people who haven’t been tested yet like Charlie or Grace seems safer. I’m happy to be on the team, but even if I’m not, I’d prefer a combo like Charlie/Grace plus just one of Bob or Eve.

I really don’t want Eve back on a team after that first fail, so I’d prefer a combo like Charlie/Grace with either me or Alice. Diana, I’m also curious why you trusted Eve enough to put her on the first mission.
Given that first mission, I really don’t want both Bob and Eve together again—I’d most trust a team like Alice, Grace, and me this round.

I get the concern about repeating the same pair, so I’d also rather not see both Bob and Eve together again this round. I’d be most comfortable with a mix like Alice or Charlie plus just one of Bob or Eve, not both.

Given the fail, I agree we shouldn’t send both Bob and me together again, but I’m more inclined to think Bob is the risky one, so I’d prefer a team like Alice, Charlie, and Grace or swapping one of them for me if people really want someone from the first mission.

I agree we shouldn’t repeat the full Bob–Eve pair, so I’d lean toward a team like Alice, Charlie, and me (or swapping Charlie for Grace) to get some new people tested while only taking one of the risky first-mission players at most.

I really don’t want to see Bob and Eve together again, and I’m also a bit wary of Diana for choosing that pair in the first place, so I’d most trust a team like Alice, Charlie, and me this round. If we have to include one of Bob/Eve later, I’d rather first get a clean read on a team with all new people.

proposals.reasoning: We know each failed mission contained at least one evil: Mission 1 had {Bob, Eve}, Mission 2 had {Alice, Charlie, Frank}. As Grace, I’m currently the only player with zero mission history, so I’m the safest anchor. To minimize overlap with the clearly suspicious pools, I want exactly one player from the Mission 2 pool and none from the Mission 1 pool. That means pairing me with either Alice or Charlie plus someone who hasn’t been on any failed team yet. Diana was not on either failed team, so she’s a strong candidate. Between Alice and Charlie, it’s symmetric in terms of evidence, but several players (including me earlier) have already coalesced around Grace–Alice–Diana as a reasonable low-overlap test team. This lineup avoids Bob and Eve entirely (since at least one of them is evil) and also keeps Frank off (since he was on the second failed mission), while testing only a single player from the second fail pool. If this mission fails, suspicion focuses sharply on Alice vs. Diana; if it succeeds, we’ve likely found a mostly clean core.

votes.comment: At 0–2 we can’t afford a high‑risk test; this lineup hinges on trusting Diana without any clearing info, and if she’s wrong or lying we likely lose. I’d rather see Grace plus two from {Alice, Charlie, Bob} and keep both Diana and Frank off for this must-hit mission.

This team almost certainly includes exactly one of Alice/Diana as evil from my perspective, and Grace is still untested; with the score at 0–2 we can’t afford a 3-player team that likely has 1–2 evils on it.

Best so far: only one member from the suspect Mission 2 pool (Alice) and none from the Bob/Eve pair, with two fresh players (Grace, Diana). If it fails, it sharply narrows blame; if it passes, we likely get a good core.
I’m on the team and it avoids the most suspicious overlaps while giving us a strong info result either way.
Team includes my known evil ally Diana; a fail here wins the game for evil.
Team matches the emerging consensus of low-overlap, Grace-anchored lineups and is a reasonable test of Alice vs. Diana while avoiding the most suspicious pools.

Best low-overlap test: I know I’m good, Diana hasn’t been on any failed team, and we only risk one from the suspicious Mission 2 pool (Alice). We avoid both Bob/Eve and Frank, and a fail sharply narrows blame to Alice vs. Diana.

discussion.content: Given both previous teams failed, I’d really like to see a lineup that excludes Diana and Frank, and maybe doesn’t put Bob and Eve together again until we get more info. I’d be more comfortable with something like a mix from Alice/Charlie/Grace plus just one of Bob or Eve.
I agree we should avoid repeating the exact pairs that have already failed—maybe start with Grace plus two from Alice/Charlie/Bob, but keep both Eve and Frank off this one for now.

I’m most comfortable treating the untouched group as safest for now, so I’d like to see a team of Charlie/Grace/Diana this round and keep all of Bob, Eve, Alice, and Frank off until we narrow down where those two fails came from.

If we assume each fail came from a different pool, the only thing we really know is that at least one of {Bob, Eve} and at least one of {Alice, Charlie, Frank} are bad. I’d be happiest with something like Grace + one of Alice/Charlie + me, and leave Bob, Eve, and Frank off this mission.

I like anchoring on Grace as the “cleanest” pick so far, then add one of Alice/Charlie plus Diana, and leave Bob, Frank, and honestly even me off this one so we get a clearer signal from a mostly new combo.

I’m fine treating Grace as the anchor here too, and I’d prefer pairing her with one of Alice/Charlie plus Diana rather than re-using Bob or Eve until we get a cleaner read. I’m also okay staying off this one myself if people are worried about overlap with the last fail.

I like anchoring on me plus one from Alice/Charlie and one from Diana/Bob, and keeping Eve and Frank off for now since both fail cards came from teams that included them. If we’re really nervous about overlaps, my first pick would be Grace–Alice–Diana.
